surprising_not_pro_ds.core_holding: The exception to the controller's obligation to provide information applies to all personal data not collected directly from the data subject, including data generated by the controller itself.

Supervisory authorities are competent to verify whether Member State law provides appropriate protective measures under Article 14(5)(c), but this does not extend to verifying Article 32 security measures.
Loss of control over personal data for a limited period may constitute compensable non-material damage if the data subject proves actual damage occurred.

The official journal is solely responsible for compliance with Article 5(1) principles for its processing operations unless national law establishes joint responsibility with other entities in the processing chain.
Judicial independence precludes indefinite extension of terms of office of members of a judicial disciplinary body without express legal basis and time limits.
A court authorizing disclosure of personal data to another judicial body is not a controller when it only verifies legal conditions without determining processing purposes.
A court authorizing data disclosure is not a supervisory authority unless entrusted by the Member State with monitoring GDPR application.
A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
A data breach by third parties is not sufficient in itself to establish that the controller's technical and organisational measures were inappropriate under Articles 24 and 32 GDPR.
An expert report cannot be a systematically necessary and sufficient means of proof for assessing the appropriateness of security measures.
The concept of "request" in Article 57(4) GDPR covers complaints lodged under Article 57(1)(f) and Article 77(1) GDPR with supervisory authorities.
National legislation may require just cause for dismissing a DPO beyond GDPR requirements, provided such legislation does not undermine GDPR objectives.
Article 82(1) GDPR precludes a de minimis threshold for non-material damage but data subjects must prove actual damage beyond mere infringement.
A GDPR infringement alone does not constitute damage; actual damage must be separately established to claim compensation under Article 82(1).
Article 38(3) GDPR does not preclude national legislation requiring just cause for DPO dismissal, even when termination is unrelated to task performance, provided GDPR objectives are not undermined.
A GDPR infringement alone does not confer a right to compensation; the data subject must prove actual damage, though no severity threshold applies.

A sectoral organization establishing binding technical rules for consent management is a joint controller even without direct data access, but controllership does not automatically extend to subsequent third-party processing.
National law may designate an auxiliary administrative entity without legal personality as controller if it can fulfil controller obligations and the law determines the scope of processing.
A non-lead supervisory authority may initiate legal proceedings regarding cross-border processing only in specific situations where GDPR confers decision-making competence on it.
The GDPR does not provide a judicial remedy for data subjects to obtain preventive injunctions against future unlawful processing, but Member States may establish such remedies under national law.
The degree of fault on the part of the controller cannot be taken into account when assessing the amount of compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
Administrative fines require intentional or negligent infringement; controllers may be fined for processor operations unless processor acted outside the agreed framework.

Employee error in providing documents containing personal data to an unauthorized third party is not sufficient in itself to conclude that the controller's technical and organizational measures were inappropriate.
When an unauthorized third party did not become aware of personal data, mere fear of future misuse does not constitute non-material damage sufficient for compensation.
An infringement of GDPR provisions conferring rights on data subjects is not sufficient in itself to constitute non-material damage requiring compensation.
The purpose limitation principle does not preclude copying personal data to a test database for testing and error correction where such processing is compatible with the initial collection purposes.
An administrative fine under Article 83 GDPR may only be imposed where the controller intentionally or negligently committed the infringement.

surprising_pro_ds.core_holding: Processing is necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b) only if objectively indispensable for the main contractual purpose, which is not met when the contract expressly prohibits disclosure.
The storage limitation principle precludes retaining personal data in a test database longer than necessary for conducting tests and correcting errors.
